comments:
Marketing Strategy views marketing as both a general management responsibility and an orientation of an organization that helps one to create, capture and sustain customer value. MKTG 777 focuses on the business unit and its network of channels, customer relationships, and alliances. Specifically, the course attempts to help develop knowledge and skills in the application of advanced marketing frameworks, concepts, and methods for making strategic choices at the business level. 

	The majority of students enjoyed MKTG 777, and described it as “excellent” and “fantastic.” Multiple students said that this was their “favorite class” and “one of the best courses at Wharton.” This was mainly due to the “interesting” topics that the course covered, such as the financial crisis and prospect theory. However, some students reported that the course material was repetitive of other courses at Wharton such as MKTG 662. Additionally, one student wished that the cases were more up to date. Nevertheless, students reported learning a lot about the course concepts, especially through class discussion.

	Overall, students had high regards for Professor Wertenbroch. They described him as an “expert in his field” and an “interesting lecturer.” Many students praised Professor Wertenbroch for his ability to facilitate class discussion. One student commented that he “knew the cases inside and out” and “asked the rights questions to provoke classroom debate.” Another student said he “made a genuine effort to make the class interesting and interactive.” Multiple students said that Professor Wertenbroch was “one of the best professors at Wharton.”

	It is important to note that the format of this course varies by instructor, but typically includes cases, lectures, group projects, and class discussions. Prerequisites for MKTG 777 include MKTG 611 or 621, and MKTG 612 or 613 or 622. This course may be taken only in the second year.
